content: The "Veterans Dog Training Therapy Act" establishes a pilot program on dog training therapy within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program to assess the effectiveness of using service dogs to address post-deployment mental health and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms in veterans with disabilities. The program will run for three to five years at selected VA medical centers, providing training for veterans with mental health conditions. The pilot program aims to train veterans with mental health conditions in service dog handling at selected VA medical centers. The training area must be wheelchair accessible, include indoor grooming and training space, classroom facilities, staff offices, equipment storage, outdoor exercise space for dogs, and provide transportation for field trips. The pilot program aims to train veterans with mental health conditions in service dog handling at selected VA medical centers. The program will be administered through the Recreation Therapy Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs under the direction of a certified recreational therapist. A director of service dog training will oversee the training of dogs at medical centers, with experience in teaching others to train service dogs in a vocational setting. Each pilot program site will have certified staff. The pilot program for training veterans with mental health conditions in service dog handling at VA medical centers includes ensuring certified service dog training instructors at each site, selecting dogs from shelters or foster homes with proper temperament and health clearances, teaching essential commands to service dogs in training, and providing both theoretical and practical training methodologies. The pilot program for training veterans with mental health conditions in service dog handling at VA medical centers includes ensuring certified service dog training instructors at each site, selecting dogs with proper temperament and health clearances, teaching essential commands, and providing theoretical and practical training. Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other post-deployment mental health conditions can volunteer if resources are available, and they may participate in conjunction with the compensated work therapy program. The program aims to maximize therapeutic benefits and provide well-trained service dogs to veterans with disabilities. The pilot program for training veterans with mental health conditions in service dog handling at VA medical centers includes hiring service dog training instructors with a preference for veterans who have graduated from treatment programs, collecting data to determine program effectiveness in reducing stigma associated with mental health conditions. The pilot program aims to help veterans with mental health conditions by training them in service dog handling. This program focuses on reducing stigma, improving emotional regulation, patience, sense of purpose, community reintegration, social skills, relaxation, sleep patterns, and reducing pain medication use. Additionally, reports to Congress are required one year after the program begins. The pilot program aims to assist veterans with mental health conditions through service dog training. Reports to Congress are required annually, detailing the number of participants, services provided, and the program's impact on symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, sobriety, suicidal ideations, and homelessness.
